article.title: Periodic accretion-powered flares from colliding EMRIs as TDE Imposters

choices: The total radiated energy of optically-selected TDE flare candidates as a function of SMBH mass.
The peak luminosity of optically-selected TDE flare candidates as a function of SMBH mass.
The time evolution of the luminosity of optically-selected TDE flare candidates.
The mass accretion rate of optically-selected TDE flare candidates as a function of time.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 2, what does the decrease in semi-major axis during the initial phase of mass transfer indicate?
choices: The star is losing mass at a rate faster than its Roche lobe is shrinking.
The star is losing mass at a rate slower than its Roche lobe is shrinking.
The star's orbit is becoming more eccentric.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the impact parameter 'b' in Figure 3?
choices: The distance between the centers of the two stars at the moment of closest approach.
The minimum distance between the outer edges of the two stars during the interaction.
The distance between the center of M1 and the outer edge of M2 at the moment of collision.
The semi-major axis of the orbit of the more massive star (M2).

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 5 suggest about the relationship between SMBH mass and the outcome of a collision between two EMRIs?
choices: Collisions around lower-mass SMBHs are more likely to result in complete stellar disruption.
Collisions around higher-mass SMBHs are more likely to result in complete stellar disruption.
The mass of the SMBH has no impact on the outcome of the collision.
Collisions are impossible around SMBHs with masses below 10^6 solar masses.
